elements.content: A series of solvent-induced Ag-based coordination polymers (CPs) (1–3), which were synthesized by regulating the size, shape, and polarity of solvent molecules (EtOH, iPrOH, 1,4-dioxane) as structure-directing agents, has been used as heterogeneous catalysts to explore how the metal–metal bonds could serve as cooperative catalysis for tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction to prepare cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles frameworks. Structural conversions from a three-dimensional (3D) framework of 1 to the structure of 2 with Ag–Ag–Ag bonds and to the two-dimensional (2D) framework of 3 with Ag–Ag bonds, arising from the different sizes, shapes, and polarities of the solvent molecules, were observed. Futhermore, the effective cooperative catalysis for tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction has been evidenced by the significantly transformed connection modes of Ag–Ag interactions in 1–3. As a result, the unique structural characteristics of 2, especially containing the Ag–Ag–Ag bonds, endow 2 with intact multinuclear reaction pathways and well-defined multinuclear platforms that can execute tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction through the cooperative effect of Ag–Ag–Ag interactions during the catalytic process.

elements.content: Three Ag-based coordination polymers (1−3) have been synthesized, and their structures could be systematically tuned by changing the size, shape, and polarity of solvent molecules as structure-directing agents. Further experiments show that 2 could work as the cooperative catalysis for the tandem acylation−Nazarov cyclization reaction to prepare cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles frameworks through the cooperative effect of Ag−Ag−Ag interactions.

elements.content: Due to the highly promising biological property and topologically fascinating ansa-bridged azafulvene macrocylic core structural unit, such as roseophilin, yuehchukene, and paspaline, it has stimulated the synthetic trial to develop an economical and green catalyst to construct the cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles frameworks. Recent research indicated that tandem pyrrole acylation–Nazarov cyclization was a greatly versatile method to construct cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles frameworks in one step with Lewis acids (e.g., ZnCl2, AlCl3, FeCl3, [Ti­(OiPr)4], [Sc­(OTf)3], BBr3) or Brønsted acids (e.g., H3PO4, HCl, TFA) as homogeneous catalysts. However, employing these catalysts under a vast variety of catalytic conditions usually generated the acylation products along with the Nazarov cyclization products since catalysts could not completely prevent the formation of catalytically incompetent oligomeric kinds by eliminating multimolecular catalyst deactivation pathways. Therefore, to alleviate these drawbacks, immobilization of homogeneous catalysts and isolation of catalytically active centers utilizing a solid support, such as coordination polymers (CPs), can give an interesting approach to execute the tandem pyrrole acylation–Nazarov cyclization to synthesize the cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles frameworks. We recently reported that highly active Lewis acids could be stabilized in Zn-based CPs via active site isolation to promote the Nazarov cyclization of pyrrole derivatives, giving the cyclized products in a good isolated yield.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Due to the highly promising biological property and topologically fascinating ansa-bridged azafulvene macrocylic core structural unit, such as roseophilin, yuehchukene, and paspaline, it has stimulated the synthetic trial to develop an economical and green catalyst to construct the cyclopentenone[b]pyrroles frameworks. Recent research indicated that tandem pyrrole acylation-Nazarov cyclization was a greatly versatile method to construct cyclopentenone[b]pyrroles frameworks in one step with Lewis acids (e.g., ZnCl2, AlCl3, FeCl3, [Ti(OiPr)4], [Sc(OTf)3], BBr3) or Brønsted acids (e.g., H3PO4, HCl, TFA) as homogeneous catalysts. However, employing these catalysts under a vast variety of catalytic conditions usually generated the acylation products along with the Nazarov cyclization products since catalysts could not completely prevent the formation of catalytically incompetent oligomeric kinds by eliminating multimolecular catalyst deactivation pathways. Therefore, to alleviate these drawbacks, immobilization of homogeneous catalysts and isolation of catalytically active centers utilizing a solid support, such as coordination polymers (CPs), can give an interesting approach to execute the tandem pyrrole acylation-Nazarov cyclization to synthesize the cyclopentenone[b]pyrroles frameworks. We recently reported that highly active Lewis acids could be stabilized in Zn-based CPs via active site isolation to promote the Nazarov cyclization of pyrrole derivatives, giving the cyclized products in a good isolated yield.

elements.content: CPs have recently emerged as a promising class of highly porous molecular materials that are already being explored as new clean energy technologies for energy applications ranging from catalysis to gas storage/separation, supercapacitor, light harvester, drug delivery, and so on. In particular, due to their highly tunable platform to engineer solid catalysts for kinds of useful organic transformations, CPs have provided great promise as single sites or cooperativity catalysts for C–C bond formation, oxidations, epoxidations, condensation, cyclization, and many other reactions. Although CPs with adjacent active sites in close proximity as cooperative catalysis have been explored, selective assembly of multimetallic active sites with strong metal–metal bonds into CPs-based catalysts for cooperative catalysis is more challenging. Metal–metal bonds have stimulated interest in characterizing multinuclear reaction pathways and developing well-defined multinuclear platforms as catalytic active sites because the remarkable use of cooperativity between two or more metal–metal interactions for activating relatively inert substrates and mediating challenging transformations have become available in enzymes catalyst system. In principle, these platforms that can trade on multimetallic cooperativity effects may show selectivity and activity profiles that diverge from a more well-established catalyst system, providing access to additional parameters for catalyst design and optimization. Furthermore, the metal–metal bonding can be cleaved, forming equilibria to enhance or depress the rate and/or selectivity of a catalytic organic transformation. Despite these advances, the synergistic effects ascribed to metal–metal bonds have rarely been evaluated in the catalytic process. Discrete metal–metal bonding often competes with metal–ligand bonding such that under catalytic conditions mononuclear/dinuclear or polynuclear species may coexist and rapidly interconvert. In order to address this limitation, direct metal–metal bonds into CPs-based catalysts are particularly well suited to capitalize on these cooperative processes due to the enforced proximity of the metals and the strong electronic coupling between them. Such studies could complement those characterizing cooperativity effects in CPs-based heterogeneous catalyst systems where sequential metal–metal interactions were thought to be involved in the catalytic organic transformation, placing particular emphasis on systems with substantial mechanistic data that correlate the presence of the metal–metal bonds with catalytic function. Although a few examples with metal–metal bonds have been documented to engage organic transformations, exerting precise control over the formation of metal–metal bonds in close proximity for cooperative/tandem catalysis in CPs is an ideal platform to improve catalytic performance.

elements.content: Herein, three Ag-based CPs, [Ag4(TTB)­(H2O)2] n (1; H4TTB = 1,2,4,5-tetra­(2H-tetrazole-5-yl)-benzene), [Ag4(TTB)­(H2O)3] n (2), and [Ag4(TTB)­(H2O)4] n (3), have been prepared via a similar synthesis method except with different solvent molecules (EtOH, iPrOH, 1,4-dioxane). The size, shape, and polarity of solvent molecules can serve as a structure-directing effect to control the formation of Ag–Ag–Ag or Ag–Ag bonds. Furthermore, we display the catalytic potentials of CPs 1–3 with reference to tandem pyrrole acylation–Nazarov cyclization for preparation of cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles frameworks. The results indicated that the catalytic activity of 2 was much higher than that of 1 and 3 because of the unique structural features of 2, namely, strong Ag–Ag–Ag interactions, which could act as the cooperative active sites to promote the tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction by the cooperative effects.

elements.content: 1,2,4,5-Tetra­(2H-tetrazole-5-yl)-benzene (H4TTB) was prepared according to a modified procedure from the literature. All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. 1H NMR spectra were obtained with a Bruker Avance-400 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported as δ (ppm) downfield with respect to an internal standard of tetramethylsilane (TMS). FT-IR spectra were recorded using a Bruker-ALPHA spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a FLASH EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on Cu Kα1 radiation on a PANalyticalX’Pert PRO diffractometer. Thermal analyses were carried out on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 in air. The atomic absorption spectrum (AAS) was performed on a Z28000 graphite-oven atomic absorption spectrophotometer. The pore size distributions of 1 and 2 were collected on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry System under ultrahigh vacuum in a clean system, with a diaphragm and turbo pumping system. Ultrahigh-purity-grade (>99.999%) N2 gas was applied in all adsorption measurements. The experimental temperature was maintained by liquid nitrogen (77 K). Prior to measurement, bulk samples of 1 and 2 were washed by ethanol (EtOH) three times, dried under vacuum, and then transferred into a stainless steel column. After 20 min of soaking and venting of supercritical CO2 (SC–CO2) by a DB-80 simplex pump, the column pressure regulator was set at 109 bar by soaking SC–CO2 and the column temperature was raised to 60 °C. SC–CO2 in the column was gradually vented after 12 h.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

1,2,4,5-Tetra(2H-tetrazole-5-yl)-benzene (H4TTB) was prepared according to a modified procedure from the literature. All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. 1H NMR spectra were obtained with a Bruker Avance-400 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported as δ (ppm) downfield with respect to an internal standard of tetramethylsilane (TMS). FT-IR spectra were recorded using a Bruker-ALPHA spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a FLASH EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on Cu Kα1 radiation on a PANalyticalX'Pert PRO diffractometer. Thermal analyses were carried out on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 in air. The atomic absorption spectrum (AAS) was performed on a Z28000 graphite-oven atomic absorption spectrophotometer. The pore size distributions of 1 and 2 were collected on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry System under ultrahigh vacuum in a clean system, with a diaphragm and turbo pumping system. Ultrahigh-purity-grade (>99.999%) N2 gas was applied in all adsorption measurements. The experimental temperature was maintained by liquid nitrogen (77 K). Prior to measurement, bulk samples of 1 and 2 were washed by ethanol (EtOH) three times, dried under vacuum, and then transferred into a stainless steel column. After 20 min of soaking and venting of supercritical CO2 (SC-CO2) by a DB-80 simplex pump, the column pressure regulator was set at 109 bar by soaking SC-CO2 and the column temperature was raised to 60 °C. SC-CO2 in the column was gradually vented after 12 h.

elements.content: To a solution of N-tosylpyrrole (1.0 mmol, 1.0 equiv), α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acid (2.0 mmol, 2.0 equiv) in dry 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE, 15 mL) was added trifluoroacetic anhydride (TFAA, 4.0 mmol, 4.0 equiv) and catalyst (0.05 mmol, 0.1 equiv based on Ag ion). The resulting mixture was refluxed for 5 h and cooled. The majority of the cool solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residue was extracted with EtOAC and H2O (3 × 15 mL). The organic phases were combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to give the pure product. The 1H NMR data of the pure products were consistent with our previous literature report.
elements.clean_text:
Typical Procedure of the Tandem Acylatione-Nazarov Cyclization Reaction for the Synthesis of Cyclopentenone[b]pyrroles Frameworks

To a solution of N-tosylpyrrole (1.0 mmol, 1.0 equiv), α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acid (2.0 mmol, 2.0 equiv) in dry 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE, 15 mL) was added trifluoroacetic anhydride (TFAA, 4.0 mmol, 4.0 equiv) and catalyst (0.05 mmol, 0.1 equiv based on Ag ion). The resulting mixture was refluxed for 5 h and cooled. The majority of the cool solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residue was extracted with EtOAC and H2O (3 × 15 mL). The organic phases were combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to give the pure product. The 1H NMR data of the pure products were consistent with our previous literature report.

elements.content: The data for 1–3 were tested on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractomer (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) at a temperature of 20 ± 1 °C). Absorption corrections were implemeted by utilizing CrystalClear (Rigaku/MSC Inc., 2006) program. The data were corrected by Lorentz and polarization effects. The whole structures were resolved by direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 with the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms were defined at calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with isotropic displacement parameters. Crystallographic crystal data and structure processing parameters for 1–3 are listed in . Selected bond lengths and bond angles for 1–3 are listed in Table S2 of the . Crystallographic data for 1–3 have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with CCDC reference numbers 1522956–1522958.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

The data for 1-3 were tested on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractomer (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) at a temperature of 20 ± 1 °C). Absorption corrections were implemeted by utilizing CrystalClear (Rigaku/MSC Inc., 2006) program. The data were corrected by Lorentz and polarization effects. The whole structures were resolved by direct methods and refined with a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 with the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms were defined at calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with isotropic displacement parameters. Crystallographic crystal data and structure processing parameters for 1-3 are listed in . Selected bond lengths and bond angles for 1-3 are listed in Table S2 of the . Crystallographic data for 1-3 have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with CCDC reference numbers 1522956-1522958.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystalizes in the triclinic space group P-1 and contains a compact 3D framework without metal–metal bonds. The asymmertic unit of 1 includes four Ag+ ions, two half-independent ligands, and two coordinated water molecules (a). In 1, two crystallographically independent Ag+ ions (Ag1 and Ag2) adopt a tricoordinated “Y-shaped” geometry and are coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three TTB4– ligands. In comparison, other two Ag+ ions (Ag3 and Ag4) are in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, where Ag3 and Ag4 are coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three TTB4– ligands and one oxygen atom from coordinated water molecule. The Ag–N and Ag–O bond distances fall within the scope from 2.171 to 2.555 Å, which are similar to the values found in other sliver complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 1 

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystalizes in the triclinic space group P-1 and contains a compact 3D framework without metal-metal bonds. The asymmertic unit of 1 includes four Ag+ ions, two half-independent ligands, and two coordinated water molecules (a). In 1, two crystallographically independent Ag+ ions (Ag1 and Ag2) adopt a tricoordinated "Y-shaped" geometry and are coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three TTB4- ligands. In comparison, other two Ag+ ions (Ag3 and Ag4) are in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, where Ag3 and Ag4 are coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three TTB4- ligands and one oxygen atom from coordinated water molecule. The Ag-N and Ag-O bond distances fall within the scope from 2.171 to 2.555 Å, which are similar to the values found in other sliver complexes.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 indicates that the four tetrazole rings are completely deprotonated and twisted relative to the central benzene ring with dihedral angles being 31.58°, 34.44°, 51.65°, and 58.62°. Each TTB4– ligand can link 12 Ag+ ions with two coordination modes (modes I and II) from the tetrazole rings in . Thus, the tetrapodal TTB4– ligand possesses four rotatable tetrazole arms to bridge the Ag+ ions, forming an unprecedented 3D framework (c). Furthermore, nitrogen sorption measurments after SC–CO2 activation indicated that the N2 uptake was very low, which clearly showed that there were no pores in 1 (). In addition, six tetrazole rings, eight Ag+ ions, and four coordinated waters could form a double-loop structure along the a axis (c).

elements.content: As expected, catenation isomerism could be realized by utilizing solvent effects, which could act as placeholders to regulate the framework, pore shapes, and properties. Therefore, the sizes and shapes of the solvent template molecules can influence the related bridging of the ligands and the coordination geometry of the metals by the steric effect. 2 was achieved under the conditions of 1 except that EtOH was replaced by iPrOH. X-ray analysis indicates that 2, which crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1, is a 3D framework consisting of the Ag–Ag–Ag bonds. Its asymmetric unit of 2 consists of 2 Ag+ ions, 1.5 TTB4– ligands, 1.5 coordinated water molecules. As shown in , Ag+ ions (Ag1 and Ag3) are four coordinated in a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Ag1 ion is four coordinated by three tetrazole N atoms of three TTB4– ligands and the adjacent Ag3 atoms, giving a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Ag2 ion (half-occupancy) is surrounded by the two tetrazole N atoms of two TTB4– ligands and one O atom from the coordinated water molecule, forming a slightly distorted T-shaped geometry, while the Ag3 (half-occupancy) is a slightly distorted plane quadrangle coordination geometry, which is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from the coordinated water molecules and two neighboring Ag atoms (Ag1 and Ag1A). Interestingly, the Ag1–Ag1A atoms are bridged together by the backbones of the Ag3 atoms and direct Ag–Ag bonds, showing a linear Ag1–Ag3–Ag1 (Ag3) cluster. Within the Ag3 cluster, the adjacent Ag–Ag separation is 3.053 Å, which is shorter than the van der Waals contact distance for two Ag atoms (3.44 Å).

Within the Ag3 cluster, the adjacent Ag-Ag separation is 3.053 Å, which is shorter than the van der Waals contact distance for two Ag atoms (3.44 Å).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 2 shows that the four tetrazole groups are completely deprotonated and twisted relative to the central benzene ring with dihedral angles being 29.09° and 69.54°, respectively. In 2, the tetrazole groups adopt the bridge mode (mode III of ) linking the Ag1 atoms and forming −Ag1–tetrazole–Ag1–tetrazole– linear chain motifs with an Ag1···Ag1 separation of 6.204 Å (a). The adjacent motifs are additionally pillared by the tetrazole groups, Ag2 and Ag3 atoms, providing a helix chain composed of the repeating −Ag2–tetrazole–Ag1–Ag3–Ag1–tetrazole–Ag2– rings. Such helix chain can be further extended into a fascinating 3D network framework via four rotatable tetrazole arms in the tetrapodal TTB4– ligand (b). Furthermore, nitrogen sorption measurments showed that 2 was a nonporous material (). Moreover, the ring-like structure is composed of eight Ag+ ions, six tetrazole rings, and six coordinated waters, which contains well-defined multinuclear platforms as catalytic active sites to promote organic transformation by the cooperative effects of Ag1–Ag3–Ag1 bonds (c).

elements.content: In consideration of the fact that the solvent polarity also has a fine influence in the morphology control and structural assembly due to the interactions between the crystal structures and the solvent molecules, 3 was achieved under the same conditions of 1 or 2 except that 1,4-dioxane was used as nonpolar solvent to replace the polar solvent (EtOH or iPrOH). The structure of 3 was obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses, and the results indicated that 3 crystallized in the triclinic space group P-1, showing a compact 2D framework with the Ag–Ag bonds. Its asymmetric unit of 3 contains four Ag+ ions, two half-independent TTB4– ligands, and four coordinated water molecules (). The four-coordinated Ag1 ions have a distored tetrahedral coordination geometry, filled by four N atoms from four different TTB4– ligands. Ag2 ion is linked by the two tetrazole N atoms of two different TTB4– ligands and one O atom from the coordinated water molecule, forming a slightly distorted T-shaped geometry. Ag3 is filled by the two tetrazole N atoms of two different TTB4– ligands, one O atom from the coordinated water molecule, and the adjacent Ag4 atoms, forming a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Ag4 ion is also in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry, where Ag4 ion is coordinated by one N atom from TTB4– ligands and two O atoms from two coordinated H2O molecules and the adjacent Ag3 atoms.

Crystal Structure of 3 

In consideration of the fact that the solvent polarity also has a fine influence in the morphology control and structural assembly due to the interactions between the crystal structures and the solvent molecules, 3 was achieved under the same conditions of 1 or 2 except that 1,4-dioxane was used as nonpolar solvent to replace the polar solvent (EtOH or iPrOH). The structure of 3 was obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses, and the results indicated that 3 crystallized in the triclinic space group P-1, showing a compact 2D framework with the Ag-Ag bonds. Its asymmetric unit of 3 contains four Ag+ ions, two half-independent TTB4- ligands, and four coordinated water molecules (). The four-coordinated Ag1 ions have a distored tetrahedral coordination geometry, filled by four N atoms from four different TTB4- ligands. Ag2 ion is linked by the two tetrazole N atoms of two different TTB4- ligands and one O atom from the coordinated water molecule, forming a slightly distorted T-shaped geometry. Ag3 is filled by the two tetrazole N atoms of two different TTB4- ligands, one O atom from the coordinated water molecule, and the adjacent Ag4 atoms, forming a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. Ag4 ion is also in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry, where Ag4 ion is coordinated by one N atom from TTB4- ligands and two O atoms from two coordinated H2O molecules and the adjacent Ag3 atoms.

elements.content: It has been indicated that the solvent effect can modulate the structural and chemical properties of CPs, but the achievement still remains a huge challenge, especially for the synthesis of CPs with metal–metal interactions. It is much more difficult to predict the finally CP topology by utilizing N-multidentate TTB4– ligand due to the much more diverse coordination modes of the ligand, influenced by solvent molecules. To obtain the structure design for heterogeneous catalysts with TTB4– ligand, the different solvent template molecules (EtOH, iPrOH, and 1,4-dioxane) were used since the coordination assemblies of specific reactants would be influenced by the size, shape, and polarity of solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Influence of Solvent on the Crystal Structures

It has been indicated that the solvent effect can modulate the structural and chemical properties of CPs, but the achievement still remains a huge challenge, especially for the synthesis of CPs with metal-metal interactions. It is much more difficult to predict the finally CP topology by utilizing N-multidentate TTB4- ligand due to the much more diverse coordination modes of the ligand, influenced by solvent molecules. To obtain the structure design for heterogeneous catalysts with TTB4- ligand, the different solvent template molecules (EtOH, iPrOH, and 1,4-dioxane) were used since the coordination assemblies of specific reactants would be influenced by the size, shape, and polarity of solvent molecules.

elements.content: By changing the solvent molecules (EtOH, iPrOH, and 1,4-dioxane), a series of Ag-based CPs (1–3) has been successfully prepared, and their structures rely on the size, shape, and polarity of solvent molecules. These characteristics of solvent molecules could influence the dihedral angle between the tetrazole rings and the central benzene ring and further affect the frameworks of the structures. Using EtOH as polar solvent, 1 indicates a 3D framework without Ag–Ag interactions and the ligands are twisted with the dihedral angle between the tetrazole rings and the central benzene ring being 31.58°, 34.44°, 51.65°, and 58.62°. Interestingly, when we used the reaction mixtures as the same conditions that are mentioned above except with a larger van der Waals volume of iPrOH () to replace EtOH, 2 was achieved as the sole product. Therefore, the result issued in the 3D framework of 1 changing to the structure of 2, in which the Ag–Ag–Ag bonds were formed. In addition, compared with the distorted H4TTB ligand in 1, the dihedral angles between the tetrazole rings and the central benzene ring of the H4TTB ligand in 2 became 29.09° and 69.54°, which was caused by the different van der Waals volumes of the solvents.

However, when 1,4-dioxane as nonpolar solvent the was used to replace EtOH or iPrOH (), 3 was achieved and showed a compact 2D framework. By contrast, the Ag–Ag bonds in 3 were also formed but the connection modes were different from 2, owing to the largest van der Waals volume of 1,4-dioxane (49.62 cm3/mol). Moreover, the H4TTB ligands in 3 return to a distorted position in which the dihedral angles of the tetrazole rings and the central benzene ring are 36.33°, 49.17°, 58.87°, and 64.62°. Therefore, a suite of Ag-based CPs (1–3) were successfully achieved under similar conditions except with different solvent molecules, which can be used as guests to influence the process of self-assembly. However, the instances indicated in this work with different sizes, shapes, and polarities of solvent molecules (EtOH, iPrOH, and 1,4-dioxane) are not present in the final framework but actually served as the structure-directing agent to regulate the coordination trend of the metal ions to form metal–metal bonds during the growth processes.

elements.content: For the tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction of N-tosylpyrrole and α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids for synthesizing cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles frameworks, it remains a synthetic challenge to develop strategies to selectively obtain Nazarov cyclization products, which are pivotal intermediates in the synthesis of numerous natural products according with the requirements of green chemistry. Inspired by the advantages of CPs as efficient cooperative catalysts for tandem cyclization reaction, we were interested in exploring whether CPs as heterogeneous cooperative catalysts could be highly catalytically active for performing the tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reactions to yield Nazarov cyclization products as the sole products.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Performance of 1-3 

For the tandem acylation-Nazarov cyclization reaction of N-tosylpyrrole and α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids for synthesizing  cyclopentenone[b]pyrroles frameworks, it remains a synthetic challenge to develop strategies to selectively obtain Nazarov cyclization products, which are pivotal intermediates in the synthesis of numerous natural products according with the requirements of green chemistry. Inspired by the advantages of CPs as efficient cooperative catalysts for tandem cyclization reaction, we were interested in exploring whether CPs as heterogeneous cooperative catalysts could be highly catalytically active for performing the tandem acylation-Nazarov cyclization reactions to yield Nazarov cyclization products as the sole products.

elements.content: Phase purity of large crystalline samples of CPs 1–3 was determined by an excellent match between the simulated and the synthesized PXRD patterns (). Moreover, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1–3 (). Furthermore, the solvent-resistance property of CPs 1–3 was tested by suspending crystals in boiling 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE) for 36 h since DCE was chosen as reaction solvent for the catalytic reaction. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analyses of solid crystals indicated that these samples could remain stable, and the keep their original shapes in boiling DCE for 36 h ().
elements.clean_text: Phase purity of large crystalline samples of CPs 1-3 was determined by an excellent match between the simulated and the synthesized PXRD patterns (). Moreover, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1-3 (). Furthermore, the solvent-resistance property of CPs 1-3 was tested by suspending crystals in boiling 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE) for 36 h since DCE was chosen as reaction solvent for the catalytic reaction. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analyses of solid crystals indicated that these samples could remain stable, and the keep their original shapes in boiling DCE for 36 h ().

elements.content: To acquire optimization of the reaction conditions for 1–3 CPs as heterogeneous catalysts in the tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction, different amounts of catalysts (1%, 3%, 5%, 10%, and 20%) were performed using N-tosylprrole, α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids, and trifluoroacetic anhydride (TFAA) in DCE at reflux for 5 h. The results indicated that when the amount of catalysts was 5%, the desired products could be produced. Subsequently, this new catalytic system was found to be general for the cyclization of N-tosylprrole with a variety of α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids, and the results are summarized in . In all instances, heterogeneous catalyst 1 could not promote the tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction (), whereas heterogeneous catalyst 3 could execute the cyclization reaction, resulting in 6a–d with moderate selectivity of the cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles products with yields ranging from 45% to 47% (). More improtantly, compared with heterogeneous catalysts 1 and 3, heterogeneous catalyst 2 obviously indicated superior activity to execute the tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction and gave Nazarov cyclization products as the sole products with yields ranging from 86% to 92% (). In comparison, the homogeneous catalyst AgPF6, a commonly utilized Lewis acid catalysts for the tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction, produced part of the Nazarov cyclization products (<21%) along with numerous byproducts under the same reaction conditions.

The results indicated that when the amount of catalysts was 5%, the desired products could be produced. Subsequently, this new catalytic system was found to be general for the cyclization of N-tosylprrole with a variety of α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids, and the results are summarized in . In all instances, heterogeneous catalyst 1 could not promote the tandem acylation-Nazarov cyclization reaction (), whereas heterogeneous catalyst 3 could execute the cyclization reaction, resulting in 6a-d with moderate selectivity of the cyclopentenone[b]pyrroles products with yields ranging from 45% to 47% (). More improtantly, compared with heterogeneous catalysts 1 and 3, heterogeneous catalyst 2 obviously indicated superior activity to execute the tandem acylation-Nazarov cyclization reaction and gave Nazarov cyclization products as the sole products with  yields ranging from 86% to 92% (). In comparison, the homogeneous catalyst AgPF6, a commonly utilized Lewis acid catalysts for the tandem acylation-Nazarov cyclization reaction, produced part of the Nazarov cyclization products (<21%) along with numerous byproducts under the same reaction conditions.

elements.content:
CPs <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold> Catalyzed Tandem acylation–Nazarov Cyclization for the Synthesis of Cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t2fn1"></xref>

Reaction conditions: N-tosylpyrrole (1.0 mmol), α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acid (2.0 mmol), catalyst (0.05 mmol), TFAA (4.0 mmol), DCE (15 mL), reflux (5h).

Isolated yield of the product after 5h.

The distinct and high selectivity of 2 can be ascribed to its specific frameworks with metal–metal bonds. Single-crystal structural study reveals that the structure of 2 contains Ag–Ag–Ag bonds, which are connected by tetrazole rings in TTB4– ligands to form a linear Ag1–Ag3–Ag1 (Ag3) cluster. The Ag3 cluster can serve as well-defined multinuclear platforms to enhance the rate and selectivity of a catalytic organic transformation. Furthermore, the catalytic active sites of Ag1–Ag3–Ag1 bonds in 2 are positioned in the frameworks periodically with indentical distances between nearest neighbors, they involve dinuclear catalysts in which substrates bind across the metal–metal bond itself. These Ag3 clusters are significant and have unique substrate–catalyst interactions that can be used to control selectivity and synergistically facilitate the catalytic reactivities to produce tandem or cooperative catalytic products. Moreover, metal–metal bonds between the same and different transition metals are strongly polarized, and the large electronegativity difference can be exploited to induce asymmerty in trinuclear or dinuclear cooperative catalytic reactions. Thus, we hypothesized that the carbonyl groups from the mixture of anhydride formation (I) can be first activated by the Ag1–Ag3 bonds in 2 to make them more electrophilic (II). Subsequently, N-tosylprrole attacked II to give pyrrolylvinylketone products III. The Ag1–Ag3 bonds may be cleaved in this process, but the dinuclear structures (Ag3–Ag1) are retained due to the presence of another active site (Ag1). Finally, the Ag3–Ag1 bonds could serve as cooperative catalysis to stabilize the cyclopenta­[b]­pyrrole (IV) by releasing H2O molecules, and the Ag1–Ag3 bonds could be recovered for the next catalytic cycle (). To test this hypothesis, experiments were conducted with AgPF6/H4TTB or H4TTB ligand as homogeneous catalysts under the same reaction conditions (). Substrates 5a–d when subjected to catalysis by AgPF6/H4TTB provided Nazarov cyclization products with yields ranging from 17% to 29% (6a–d), whereas homogeneous catalyst H4TTB ligand gave no cyclization products. These yields were much lower than the 86–92% yields obtained with heterogeneous catalyst 2 because the catalyst AgPF6/H4TTB might be relatively simple coordination complexes, comprising a single metal center bound only to the organic components. Futhermore, considerable studies have been carried out on the structure of 2 with XPS, aiming to reveal their correlations with the observed Ag–Ag–Ag interactions in the catalyst during the different reaction times (0, 2.5, and 5 h). Accordingly, it was found that the chemical states of Ag in the reaction processes exist uniquely as Ag+, associated with the Ag 3d2/5 XPS signals at 367.58, 367.26, and 367.79 eV (a). The results indicated that when the reaction times were 0, 2.5, and 5 h, the Ag+ peaks showed a shift. The Ag–Ag–Ag bonds could be cleaved and formed the transient state (Ag···Ag–Ag), which still kept the dinuclear structures to promote the cyclization reactions by a synergistic effect. In addition, to further explain the reaction process, energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) and mapping were used to observe the catalysts and substrate changes. Aimed at obtaining elemental changes on the catalysts, the different reaction times (0, 2.5, and 5 h) were carefully controlled to study the changing processes. shows EDS spectra of the different reaction times, which clearly display the C, O, N, S, and Ag element changes on 2. The contribution of S to the spectrum was attributed to the N-tosylprrole substrate used during the cyclization reaction. To further investigate the distribution of C, O, N, S, and Ag, corresponding element mapping measurements were executed. The mapping images clearly indicate the distribution of C, O, N, S, and Ag components in the different reaction times (c and d).

elements.content: In contrast, single-crystal X-ray structure analysis revealed that 1 only has the 3D framework, while the Ag–Ag bonds do not exist in the structure. The result leads one to conclude that 1 can serve as single-site catalysts to provide the platform to ensure that the acylation reaction was executed. Just the opposite, single-crystal structural analysis indicates that 3 has a compact 2D framework with the Ag–Ag bonds. Although the Nazarov cyclization products can be produced by using 3 as heterogeneous catalysts due to the Ag–Ag interactions, the yields were much lower than the 86–92% yields obtained with heterogeneous catalyst 2. This is because only one metal center in Ag–Ag bonds (Ag3 or Ag4) was involved in substrate binding, while the second served as a supporting metalloligand. In this case, the catalytic intermediates that were formed often closely resemble those using monomer–dimer catalysts, leading to formation of both the Nazarov cyclization products and the acylation products. Compared with 1, 3, AgPF6, and AgPF6/H4TTB, 2 could serve as a more efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclizaion reactions with pyrrole and α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids due to the fact that Ag–Ag–Ag bonds can afford multinuclear platforms to facilitate the reaction and display the cooperative effect, giving Nazarov cyclization product as the single product.
elements.clean_text: In contrast, single-crystal X-ray structure analysis revealed that 1 only has the 3D framework, while the Ag-Ag bonds do not exist in the structure. The result leads one to conclude that 1 can serve as  single-site catalysts to provide the platform to ensure that the acylation reaction was executed. Just the opposite, single-crystal structural analysis indicates that 3 has a compact 2D framework with the Ag-Ag bonds. Although the Nazarov cyclization products can be produced by using 3 as heterogeneous catalysts due to the Ag-Ag interactions, the yields were much lower than the 86-92% yields obtained with heterogeneous catalyst 2. This is because only one metal center in Ag-Ag bonds (Ag3 or Ag4) was involved in substrate binding, while the second served as a supporting metalloligand. In this case, the catalytic intermediates that were formed often closely resemble those using monomer-dimer catalysts, leading to  formation of both the Nazarov cyclization products and the acylation products. Compared with 1, 3, AgPF6, and AgPF6/H4TTB, 2 could serve as a more efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the tandem acylation-Nazarov cyclizaion reactions with pyrrole and α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids due to the fact that Ag-Ag-Ag bonds can afford multinuclear platforms to facilitate the reaction and display the cooperative effect, giving Nazarov cyclization product as the single product.

elements.content: To further confirm that activation of the Nazarov cyclization reactions occurred on the surface rather than in the crystal voids, a bulky demanding substrate 5d was subjected to carry out the Nazarov cyclization reaction with large cystalline sampes of 2 (∼0.28 × 0.27 × 0.25 mm3) without grinding or stirring. An 81% yield was achieved after 5 h, which was slighter lower than the 86% yield achieved with grinding or stirring. Furthermore, nitrogen sorption measurments after SC–CO2 activation indicated that the exerimentally determined BET surface areas was 1.2358 m2 g–1. In further studies, due to the very low N2 uptake (), the pore size distributions (PSDs) of 2 could not be afforded, which clearly showed that there were no pores in 2. Moreover, PLATON analysis provided no free void volume ratio of 2, which further suggented that 2 was a completely nonporous material. Thus, these resluts afforded unambiguous evidence that the cyclization reactions took place on the surface of the crystals with a cooperative effect rather than in the interior of the crystals. Moreover, to research the influence of the coordinated water molecules for the cyclization reaction, crystalline samples of 2 were activated in a drying oven at 235 °C to exclude the coordinated water molecules () and formed the activated samples 2a. Subsequently, cyclization of 4 and 5a was carried out with activated samples of 2a under the same reaction conditions. A 94% yield was obtained by using the activated samples of 2a after 5 h; this clearly demonstrated that the coordinated water molecules were good leaving groups and would be advantageous to make contact with organic substrates with the catalytic active centers in the catalytic process.

An 81% yield was achieved after 5 h, which was slighter lower than the 86% yield achieved with grinding or stirring. Furthermore, nitrogen sorption measurments after SC-CO2 activation indicated that the exerimentally determined BET surface areas was 1.2358 m2 g-1. In further studies, due to the very low N2 uptake (), the pore size distributions (PSDs) of 2 could not be afforded, which clearly showed that there were no pores in 2. Moreover, PLATON analysis provided no free void volume ratio of 2, which further suggented that 2 was a completely nonporous material. Thus, these resluts afforded unambiguous evidence that the cyclization reactions took place on the surface of the crystals with a cooperative effect rather than in the interior of the crystals. Moreover, to research the influence of the coordinated water molecules for the cyclization reaction, crystalline samples of 2 were activated in a drying oven at 235 °C to exclude the coordinated water molecules () and formed the activated samples 2a. Subsequently,  cyclization of 4 and 5a was carried out with activated samples of 2a under the same reaction conditions. A 94% yield was obtained by using the activated samples of 2a after 5 h; this clearly demonstrated that the coordinated water molecules were good leaving groups and would be advantageous to make contact with organic substrates with the catalytic active centers in the catalytic process.

elements.content: To examine whether the cyclization reactions were homogeneous or heterogeneous, the leaching of silver from the crystalline sampes of 2 during the cyclization reaction was first examined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) analysis, and only slight leaching (<1 ppm) was achieved. Second, a filtration experiment was carried out. After 24% conversion of 4 in the presence of large crystalline samples of 2 without grinding or stirring for 1 h, the reaction mixture was filtered through a sand core funnel to transfer the catalysts and the supernatant was allowed to react for another 4 h. It was found that the conversion of the supernatant remained nearly unchanged during this time. Therefore, these results unambiguously displayed that 2 was a true heterogeneous catalyst.
elements.clean_text: To examine whether the cyclization reactions were homogeneous or heterogeneous, the leaching of silver from the crystalline sampes of 2 during the cyclization reaction was first examined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) analysis, and only slight leaching (<1 ppm) was achieved. Second, a filtration experiment was carried out. After 24% conversion of 4 in the presence of large crystalline samples of 2 without grinding or stirring for 1 h, the reaction mixture was filtered through a sand core funnel to transfer the catalysts and the supernatant was allowed to react for another 4 h. It was found that the conversion of the supernatant remained nearly unchanged during this time. Therefore, these results unambiguously displayed that 2 was a true heterogeneous catalyst.

elements.content: The recyclability of 2 for the catalytic reaction of 4 and 5a was also examined to evaluate the stability of the heterogeneous catalysts. In the recyclability experiments, 2 could be readily recovered from the catalytic reaction by centrifugation, and the recovered catalyst showed only slight deterioration after five runs (). Furthermore, the PXRD patterns of the samples of 2 after the fifth catalytic reaction closely matched those of single crystals of 2 and indicated no signs of framework collapse and decomposition, which showed that the framework could keep intact after at least five runs. Moreover, the SEM images of solid catalysts after five runs have also been examined. As shown in c and d, these samples showed similar morphologies consisting of an irregular particle with a vast particle size distribution, which was probably the reasons for the high catalytic activity and recyclability for reuse.

elements.content: In summary, with diffierernt solvent template molecules as structure-directing agents (EtOH, iPrOH, and 1,4-dioxane), a series of catalytically active Ag­(I)-based CPs 1–3 was successfully regulated and controlled by solvent-induced effects. The structures of 1–3 could be systematically adjusted by the size, shape, and polarity of solvent molecules. The interactions between the solvent molecules and the configuration of the ligand H4TTB could influence the formation of the Ag–Ag–Ag or Ag–Ag bonds and further regulate the structures of the frameworks. Furthermore, systematically tuning the metal–metal bonds of CPs was obtained only by changing the size, shape, and polarity of introduced solvent molecules. Moreover, with well-defined Ag–Ag–Ag bonds, 2 could act as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for tandem acylation–Nazarov cyclization reaction with pyrrole and α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids, provide a platform to highlight cases where there is substantial evidence for involvement of metal–metal bonds in the catalytic process, emphasizing the impact of the metal–metal interaction in tuning the activity and/or selectivity of a catalyst, and also display cooperative catalysis in forming cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, with diffierernt solvent template molecules as structure-directing agents (EtOH, iPrOH, and 1,4-dioxane), a series of catalytically active Ag(I)-based CPs 1-3 was successfully regulated and controlled by solvent-induced effects. The structures of 1-3 could be systematically adjusted by the size, shape, and polarity of solvent molecules. The interactions between the solvent molecules and the configuration of the ligand H4TTB could influence the formation of the Ag-Ag-Ag or Ag-Ag bonds and further regulate the structures of the frameworks. Furthermore, systematically tuning the metal-metal bonds of CPs was obtained only by changing the size, shape, and polarity of introduced solvent molecules. Moreover, with well-defined Ag-Ag-Ag bonds, 2 could act as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for tandem acylation-Nazarov cyclization reaction with pyrrole and α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids, provide a platform to highlight cases where there is substantial evidence for involvement of metal-metal bonds in the catalytic process, emphasizing the impact of the metal-metal interaction in tuning the activity and/or selectivity of a catalyst, and also display  cooperative catalysis in  forming  cyclopentenone[b]pyrroles frameworks.

AgNO3 (0.034 g, 0.2 mmol), H4TTB (0.017 g, 0.05 mmol), EtOH (4 mL), and NH3·H2O (4 mL) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The mixture was sealed and heated at 160 °C for 3 days. After the mixture was cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h; colorless crystals of 1 were obtained with a yield of 53% (based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C10H6Ag4N16O2: C, 24.51; H, 1.23; N, 45.72. Found: C, 24.54; H, 1.21; N, 45.69. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3325 (s), 3155 (m), 2167 (w), 1980 (vw), 1631 (m), 1513 (w), 1406 (vs), 1132­(m), 1010 (m), 917 (vs), 756 (s), 721 (vw).

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>4</sub>(TTB)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Synthesis of 2 was similar to complex 1, except that iPrOH was used instead of EtOH. After the mixture was cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h, colorless crystals of 2 were obtained with a yield of 49% (based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C10H8Ag4N16O3: C, 23.73; H, 1.19; N, 44.28. Found: C, 23.71; H, 1.22; N, 44.31. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3326 (s), 3216 (m), 2167 (w), 2040 (vw), 1612 (m), 1406 (vs), 1353 (vw), 1102­(m), 1011 (w), 917 (s), 753 (w), 721 (vw).

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>4</sub>(TTB)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Synthesis of 3 was similar to complex 1, except that 1,4-dioxane was used instead of EtOH. After the mixture was cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h, colorless crystals of 3 were obtained with a yield of 41% (based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C10H10Ag4N16O4: C, 23.00; H, 1.16; N, 42.92. Found: C, 23.04; H, 1.14; N, 42.95. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3324 (s), 3156 (w), 2167 (vw), 2032 (vw), 1631 (m), 1406 (vs), 1100(s), 1009 (s), 917 (m), 756 (w), 721 (vw).

Typical Procedure of the Tandem Acylatione–Nazarov Cyclization Reaction for the Synthesis of Cyclopentenone­[b]­pyrroles Frameworks

To a solution of N-tosylpyrrole (1.0 mmol, 1.0 equiv), α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acid (2.0 mmol, 2.0 equiv) in dry 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE, 15 mL) was added trifluoroacetic anhydride (TFAA, 4.0 mmol, 4.0 equiv) and catalyst (0.05 mmol, 0.1 equiv based on Ag ion). The resulting mixture was refluxed for 5 h and cooled. The majority of the cool solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residue was extracted with EtOAC and H2O (3 × 15 mL). The organic phases were combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel to give the pure product. The 1H NMR data of the pure products were consistent with our previous literature report.

metadata.title:
Solvent-Induced Assembly of Sliver Coordination Polymers
(CPs) as Cooperative Catalysts for Synthesizing of Cyclopentenone[b]pyrroles Frameworks
